meanings.def: the top outside floor of a ship or boat
examples: on deck I was the only person on deck at that time of night.
When we heard the alarm, we went up on deck.
below deck(s) As the storm began, everyone disappeared below deck(s).

meanings.def: one of the floors of a ship or a bus
examples: the upper/lower/main deck of a ship
We sat on the top deck of the bus.
My cabin is on deck C.

meanings.def: a floor or platform similar to the deck of a ship
examples: There is an open-air observation deck on the building's top floor.
He fell from the upper deck of the car park.

meanings.def: a complete set of 52 playing cards
a wooden floor that is built outside the back of a house where you can sit and relax
examples: After dinner we sat out on the deck.

meanings.def: a part of a sound system that records and/or plays sounds on a disc or tape
a set of slides (= pages created on a computer that contain text and images) that are used to accompany a personâ€™s presentation
examples: Three slides into my 35-slide deck, they asked me to turn off the projector.

meanings.def: everyone helps or must help, especially in a difficult situation
examples: There are 30 people coming to dinner tonight, so it's all hands on deck.

meanings.def: to prepare for an activity, event, etc. by removing anything that is not essential to it

idioms.def: everyone helps or must help, especially in a difficult situation
examples: There are 30 people coming to dinner tonight, so it's all hands on deck.

idioms.def: to prepare for an activity, event, etc. by removing anything that is not essential to it

examples: be decked out in/with something The room was decked out in flowers and balloons.
be decked in/with something The Conservative candidate and his supporters were decked in blue rosettes.
deck something (with something) Deck the halls with boughs of holly!

meanings.def: to hit somebody very hard so that they fall to the ground
